text: Family Member: it’s radium for sure? Doctor: Well, it’s radium as an option. You know, you guys might look at that and go um, I don’t know how I feel about it and after you talk to the radiation doctor who administers it, you know, some people might say oh, gosh, I just worried about it and I’d rather take chemo and that’s okay too. I’m just trying to make it so easy. I mean any and all of this is interchangeable. If you had just bone only, you could get chemo Patient: Okay. Doctor: but if you have not just bone you can’t get radium. So, radium is only good for one thing. You got bone you can get radium. Patient: Radium. Doctor: It can’t go anywhere else. So, if it’s anywhere else other than bone, no go on the radium. Taxotere, you know, chemo could be anywhere anytime, less picky. Patient: What happened to the radiation that I took for the forty some days? Whatever did that do any good or it did nothing or what? Doctor: Well, I think it’s controlling your local, you know. Patient: You think it made a difference? Okay. Doctor: Oh, yeah. Oh, I think so. Yeah, those aren’t the problem cells. Those guys are dumb and dead. It’s the smarter ones that are like party. They may have not been even in the field of radiation. They may have already been floating around. So, just to also make sure we talk about the genetics stuff that you did because the biopsy didn’t really yield anything… Patient: Right, okay, that’s one of the things. Doctor: Yeah, right, it kind of all went south after that but we did check your blood. If you remember we sent a couple of tubes to a company called Guardian Health Patient: Yes.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: What else? Patient: And for how long does this study last? Doctor: As long as you respond, we keep going. So if you are side effects, or too much, or you're like, Listen, I'm just done, we stop. If you say my gosh, this thing is really good. And I'm doing great, we keep going. And it's we can't take the drug away from you. Sometimes that's to the irritation of the pharma company, because sometimes they want to get out after a year, but it's actually interesting. One of my other studies, somebody's been on two years longer than they thought, and they want to close it. And we're like, well, I'm sorry, my one guy's doing great. So you can't take it away from us. So there's that other option, but in general, it's you who calls it quits or that the cancer’s has moved on. And if that's happened, we got to stop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Mhm. Patient: Cancer. The cancer subsided or it can't reverse cancer get worse. Doctor: The cancer has gotten worse and moved on to new spots or new areas. Oh, you know, it's not gonna be shy. It'll tell us. Yeah. So at this moment is just sort of the slow creep, you know, it’s the- What do you mean? It's six right? I mean, you haven't way in the beginning you were near 300 there but you've always been super low. So when we look at you, it's like this tiny little rises but nothing that's like this. Yeah, Patient: Just a quick note- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - it started out much higher than that. I think you get Doctor: Yeah, no, no, I had you correct. Yeah, we met each other after your stuff started but in our system, that's as high as you been?

text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: We have shown that to be true in the laboratory both in cancer cells which are being grown in a plastic dish in the lab. Patient: Right. Doctor: In mostly mice that have prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In humans we have some preliminary data that this is true. We have not conclusively proven that. And there are clearly patients who do not respond to this therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now one question that patients always ask me is “Is it possible you know for the uh testosterone to make the cancer worse?” In other words, could it accelerate or stimulate or speed up the cancer? Patient: Uh huh. My thoughts also. Doctor: And you know that was one of the very first things we thought of when we were designing these trials for uh patients and the first trial of this approach started in around twenty thirteen. And so we’ve been doing this for three or four years now. And in our initial studies, fortunately we did not see any cases where prostate cancer appeared to accelerate. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So we basically saw one of three patterns. Patient: Uh huh.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: …is that this is all related to the prostate cancer. So um I don’t think there’s any reason for me to believe or doubt that this is gonna be the prostate cancer. It’s theoretically possible it could be a gist. All right. I think it’s extremely, extremely unlikely. Patient: And how would we know? I knew your recommendation was that since it’s a low level in in the lymph node… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: - um that it’s something you wouldn’t biopsy, but um I guess - Doctor: The best way to find out in my opinion – Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - is open for discussion is to treat this as if it was a prostate cancer and see if it goes away. Patient: Okay, so - Doctor: And if it does, and in retrospect, because if we give you a hormone therapy, for example and it’s a gist, it will not increase sized at all. Patient: Correct. Doctor: If it’s a hormone therapy and it’s prostate cancer, you know it’s gonna disappear or decrease by ninety percent within the first few months. Patient: Okay, would that be your recommendation, to do more hormonal?

text: Patient: Oh. Doctor: And so, this study is looking at a new therapy –uh, the hottest new drugs that are out there, and when we’ve given them to men with prostate cancer, we haven’t seen a whole lot. (Pause) Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Um. And the two drugs together, uh, may be, uh, cause responses. Uh, but we don’t know. And that’s why we’re doing a research study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we’re giving folks who’ve got bad disease this because the worry is these drugs may have a lot of side effects. Most of the time, they’re tolerated well, but what they do is they turn on your immune system, hope that your immune system is going to attack your cancer, but I also could turn on your immune system with these medicines and it attacks you. Okay? So you can get a pneumonia that’s from your immune system. You can get hepatitis because it’s attacking your liver. You could get colitis ‘cuz it’s attacking your colon. Uh, it usually picks one organ, not not all of ‘em, but, you know, you can get into trouble because your immune system – while it’s tryin’ to fight your cancer, it’s tryin’ to fight you. Uh. And when we Patient: I see. This is from the – both the uh– the, uh, both of the – Doctor: Both ipilimumab and nivolumab. Patient: Okay. (laughs) Doctor: Big words. Patient: Who makes these things up? Doctor: They don’t want us to use -- they want us to use a Yervoy and Opdivo – the shorter ones, but they have big names so if we don’t use them – but I have to use ‘em. Patient: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
